Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2018 IEEE International Conference on Computer Communications (INFOCOM)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The IEEE International Conference on Computer Communications (INFOCOM) is a premier international conference, held annually, covering a wide spectrum of theoretical and applied research in the networking field. The conference provides an unique platform for world-leading researchers and practitioners to present their latest research results. Attending such a high-caliber technical event, with multiple technical sessions and workshops, is important for graduate students' professional development. The students will have the opportunity to present their work and be exposed to the state-of-the-art developments in the field. They will also have the opportunity to interact with peers from institutions worldwide, meet with leading researchers, and participate in discussions that are likely to shape the future of the field.

This award will support approximately 20 students in the United States to attend the 2018 IEEE INFOCOM conference which will be held in Honolulu, Hawaii from April 15 to April 19, 2018. The travel grants will target graduate students who will substantially benefit from attending this conference but have limited travel funds. Priority will be given to first time attendees,especially those without papers, and students from under-represented groups (female, minorities and students with disabilities).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018 IEEE INFOCOM Conference on Computer Communications was held in Hawaii, HI, USA from April 15 to April 19, 2018. This preeminent technical conference is the primary venue for presenting new research results in the area of computer communications and is widely attended by researchers and practitioners in the field. The program consists of technical sessions, workshops, panels, and tutorials. The acceptance rate of INFOCOM 2018 was 19.2% (typically between 17% and 22% since 2004), which indicates the high quality of the conference. Due to the high volume of submissions from the US, the participation level from US participants was high: the conference had more than 1,000 participants from more than 40 countries, and more than half of the participants were from US. Attending such a high-caliber conference is extremely valuable for graduate students’ education and long-term career development. By providing the travel support, this project contributes to the training of the future researchers in the field of computer communications and networking.

This project provided funding support to 20 students in the United States to attend this premiere conference and one additional graduate student in the US to attend INFOCOM 2019. Among all the applicants, 42.5% were selected to receive the travel support, with priorities given to women, under-represented minority students, first-time attendees, and students who would substantially benefit from attending the conference. All awardees attended the conference. Out of the 21 awardees from 14 states and 18 universities, 9 are female students, one is Native American undergraduate student, and majority of the awardees are first-time attendees. The awards were decided by the award selection committee consisting of two professors, and conflicts-of-interest have been avoided during the selection process.

The awardees expressed their deep appreciation for the NSF travel support and acknowledged the great value and importance of attending the conference. They not only had the opportunities of presenting their work, learning the state-of-the-art research, participating panel discussions, but also were able to meet new colleagues, and interact with hundreds of others performing cutting-edge research in the field.
